title: The great brain debate - Ted Altschuler

multiple-choice.question: Who were the two scientists that got into a brainy argument about how speech and memory operated within the human brain in 1861?

options.label: B
options.text: René Descartes and Franz Joseph Gall

multiple-choice.question: According to Franz Joseph Gall, what was the reason for the best memorizers in his class having the most prominent eyes?

options.label: A
options.text: Higher development in the adjacent part of the brain

options.label: B
options.text: Higher development in the frontal lobe

options.label: C
options.text: Higher development in the temporal lobe

options.label: D
options.text: Higher development in the occipital lobe

multiple-choice.question: Who challenged phrenology by selectively destroying parts of animal brains and observing which functions were lost?
What was the conclusion of Pierre Flourens' study on selectively destroying parts of animal brains?

options.label: A
options.text: That the cortex carried out brain functions as an entire unit

options.label: B
options.text: That the cortex carried out brain functions as separate units

options.label: C
options.text: That the frontal lobe was responsible for speech production

options.label: D
options.text: That the temporal lobe was responsible for speech comprehension

multiple-choice.question: What was the finding of Jean-Baptiste Bouillaud's study on patients with speech disorders?

options.label: A
options.text: That the frontal lobe was responsible for speech production

options.label: B
options.text: That the temporal lobe was responsible for speech comprehension

options.label: C
options.text: That the cortex carried out brain functions as an entire unit

options.label: D
options.text: That the hippocampus was responsible for memory formation

multiple-choice.question: Who associated part of the left temporal lobe with speech comprehension in the 1870s?
What was the idea proposed by Karl Wernicke?

options.label: A
options.text: That the regions for speech production and comprehension were adjacent

options.label: B
options.text: That the regions for speech production and comprehension were not adjacent

options.label: C
options.text: That the cortex carried out brain functions as an entire unit

options.label: D
options.text: That the hippocampus was responsible for memory formation

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the hippocampus according to modern neuroscience?

options.label: A
options.text: Creating memories and processing location in space

options.label: C
options.text: Processing location in space and processing emotions

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between anatomical and functional connectivity according to modern neuroscience?

options.label: A
options.text: Anatomical connectivity refers to the connection between two adjoining regions of cortex, while functional connectivity refers to the connection between separated regions working together to accomplish one process

options.label: B
options.text: Anatomical connectivity refers to the connection between separated regions working together to accomplish one process, while functional connectivity refers to the connection between two adjoining regions of cortex

options.label: C
options.text: Anatomical connectivity refers to the connection between the hippocampus and the cortex, while functional connectivity refers to the connection between the cortex and the brainstem

options.label: D
options.text: Anatomical connectivity refers to the connection between the brainstem and the cortex, while functional connectivity refers to the connection between the hippocampus and the cortex

multiple-choice.question: What is the current understanding of how cognition happens according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Both Gratiolet's and Aubertin's models are correct, and they are used to understand how cognition happens

options.label: B
options.text: Only Gratiolet's model is correct, and it is used to understand how cognition happens

options.label: C
options.text: Only Aubertin's model is correct, and it is used to understand how cognition happens

options.label: D
options.text: Neither Gratiolet's nor Aubertin's model is correct, and a new model is needed to understand how cognition happens

title: How do scars form? - Sarthak Sinha

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary location where scars are commonly seen?
What is the term for the arrangement of structural proteins, like collagen, that allows for transportation of nutrients, cell-to-cell communication, and cell adhesion in healthy skin tissue?
What happens to the arrangement of ECM in the skin when a deep wound occurs?

options.label: C
options.text: It becomes aligned in a single direction

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the new ECM being aligned in a single direction after a wound?
What is the term for the presence of excessive fibrous connective tissue in an organ?
What is a genetic disorder that causes scarring of the pancreas?
What is a condition that results from scarring of the lungs, leading to shortness of breath?
What is a condition that can occur when the buildup of ECM following a heart attack inhibits the heart's beating?
What is the goal of medical researchers studying what causes fibroblast cells to secrete excessive amounts of collagen?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand how to better control wound healing

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how to prevent scarring

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how to treat fibrosis

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how to regenerate damaged tissue

options.label: B
options.text: Improved quality of life for millions of people

options.label: D
options.text: Development of new treatments for fibrosis

title: How a wound heals itself - Sarthak Sinha

multiple-choice.question: What is the surface area of the human skin in adults?
What is the main function of the epidermis in the human skin?

options.label: B
options.text: To devour bacteria and damage tissue

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the process where fibroblast cells produce collagen in the wound site?

options.label: D
options.text: To contain blood vessels and glands

options.label: D
options.text: The skin may never fully recover

options.label: A
options.text: To develop new treatments for skin conditions

options.label: B
options.text: To improve the tensile strength of the skin

options.label: C
options.text: To find the answers to fundamental mysteries of the healing process

title: Ideasthesia: How do ideas feel? - Danko Nikolić

multiple-choice.question: What is the traditional model of our mental function, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The senses provide separate data to our brain which are then translated into the appropriate mental phenomena.

options.label: B
options.text: The brain provides separate data to our senses which are then translated into the appropriate mental phenomena.

options.label: C
options.text: The senses and brain work together to create mental phenomena.

options.label: D
options.text: The mental phenomena are created by external stimuli.

options.label: A
options.text: The higher level ideas and concepts that our minds associate with the sensory input must be activated.

options.label: B
options.text: The sensory input must be intense.

options.label: C
options.text: The sensory input must be weak.

options.label: D
options.text: The sensory input must be absent.

options.label: A
options.text: They live on separate sensory islands.

options.label: B
options.text: They are organized in a network of associations similar to our language network.

options.label: C
options.text: They are unrelated to each other.

options.label: D
options.text: They are determined by external stimuli.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Ideasthesia is a hindrance to art.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the traditional view of how our senses and mind work together?

options.label: A
options.text: Our senses first capture a collection of colors and shapes, and our mind then classifies them as a tree or a siren.

options.label: B
options.text: Our mind first classifies the sensory input, and then our senses capture the colors and shapes.

options.label: C
options.text: Our senses and mind work together simultaneously.

options.label: D
options.text: Our senses and mind do not work together.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the implication of the ideasthesia model for our understanding of our selves and our relation to the world around us?

options.label: A
options.text: It suggests that our selves are separate from the world around us.

options.label: B
options.text: It suggests that our selves are an integral part of the world around us.

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that our selves are unrelated to the world around us.

options.label: D
options.text: It suggests that our selves are determined by external stimuli.

title: How do germs spread (and why do they make us sick)? - Yannay Khaikin and Nicole Mideo

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question:
Conceptual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that germs evolve to become more virulent over time

options.label: B
options.text: The concept that germs will evolve to maximize their overall success by achieving a balance between replicating within a host and transmission to a new host

options.label: C
options.text: The notion that germs only evolve in response to environmental factors

options.label: D
options.text: The theory that germs can only be eradicated through the use of antibiotics

multiple-choice.question: Application Question:

options.label: A
options.text: Stay home and take medication to reduce symptoms

options.label: B
options.text: Avoid close contact with others and stay home to prevent spreading the virus

options.label: C
options.text: Go to the gym to improve your immune system

options.label: D
options.text: Take antibiotics to kill the virus[Answer]: B: Avoid close contact with others and stay home to prevent spreading the virus

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question:

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are more likely to infect multiple hosts

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are less likely to be detected by the host's immune system

options.label: C
options.text: Because they rely on the host being immobile to facilitate transmission

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are more likely to cause harm to the host's tissues[Answer]: C: Because they rely on the host being immobile to facilitate transmission

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question:
Conceptual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: There is no relationship between the two

options.label: B
options.text: Germs that are transmitted through close contact tend to be less virulent

options.label: C
options.text: Germs that are transmitted through vectors such as insects tend to be more virulent

options.label: D
options.text: Germs that are transmitted through food and water tend to be less virulent[Answer]: B: Germs that are transmitted through close contact tend to be less virulent

multiple-choice.question: Application Question:

options.label: A
options.text: By using antibiotics to kill them

options.label: B
options.text: By creating a clean environment that prevents the spread of germs

options.label: C
options.text: By using mosquito-proofing houses and establishing clean water systems

options.label: D
options.text: By staying homeopathy[Answer]: C: By using mosquito-proofing houses and establishing clean water systems

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question:

options.label: A
options.text: Germs that replicate quickly within a host tend to be less virulent

options.label: B
options.text: Germs that transmit quickly to a new host tend to be less virulent

options.label: C
options.text: Germs that replicate quickly within a host tend to be more virulent

options.label: D
options.text: Germs that transmit slowly to a new host tend to be more virulent[Answer]: C: Germs that replicate quickly within a host tend to be more virulent

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question:

options.label: D
options.text: Dr. Charles Darwin[Answer]: A: Dr. Paul Ewald

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: The common cold is caused by the rhinovirus

options.label: B
options.text: The rhinovirus is a common cause of the common cold

options.label: C
options.text: The common cold is not caused by the rhinovirus

options.label: D
options.text: The rhinovirus is a rare cause of the common cold[Answer]: B: The rhinovirus is a common cause of the common cold

title: What is the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle? - Chad Orzel

multiple-choice.question: What is the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle?

options.label: A
options.text: A principle that states that an object can have both a definite position and a definite speed.

options.label: B
options.text: A principle that states that an object can never simultaneously know the exact position and the exact speed of an object.

options.label: C
options.text: A principle that states that an object can only have a definite position or a definite speed.

options.label: D
options.text: A principle that states that an object can have both a definite position and a definite speed, but only at the same time.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the reason for the uncertainty principle?

options.label: A
options.text: The act of measuring an object's position changes its speed.

options.label: B
options.text: The real origin of the uncertainty principle is much deeper and more amazing.

options.label: C
options.text: Everything in the universe behaves like both a particle and a wave at the same time.

options.label: D
options.text: The uncertainty principle is a result of measurement, not a fundamental property of the universe.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key difference between a particle and a wave?

options.label: A
options.text: A particle exists in a single place at any instant in time, while a wave is a disturbance spread out in space.

options.label: B
options.text: A particle is a disturbance spread out in space, while a wave exists in a single place at any instant in time.

options.label: C
options.text: A particle has a definite position and speed, while a wave has a definite wavelength and momentum.

options.label: D
options.text: A particle has a definite wavelength and momentum, while a wave has a definite position and speed.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between an object's wavelength and its momentum?

options.label: A
options.text: An object's wavelength is related to its mass, but not its velocity.

options.label: B
options.text: An object's wavelength is related to its mass times velocity.

options.label: C
options.text: An object's wavelength is related to its velocity, but not its mass.

options.label: D
options.text: An object's wavelength is unrelated to its momentum.

multiple-choice.question: Why don't we notice the wave nature of everyday objects?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the wavelengths of everyday objects are too large to measure.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the wavelengths of everyday objects are too small to measure.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the wavelengths of everyday objects are related to their mass and velocity.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the wavelengths of everyday objects are unrelated to their mass and velocity.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when we add two waves together?

options.label: A
options.text: The peaks of the two waves cancel each other out.

options.label: B
options.text: The valleys of the two waves cancel each other out.

options.label: C
options.text: The result has regions where the peaks line up, making a bigger wave.

options.label: D
options.text: The result has regions where the valleys line up, making a bigger wave.

multiple-choice.question: What is a wave packet?

options.label: A
options.text: A single wave with a definite wavelength and momentum.

options.label: B
options.text: A combination of waves with different wavelengths, which gives the object a probability of having different momenta.

options.label: C
options.text: A wave with a definite position and speed.

options.label: D
options.text: A particle with a definite position and momentum.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what happens when we try to reduce the position uncertainty of a wave packet?

options.label: A
options.text: We need to add more waves, which means a bigger momentum uncertainty.

options.label: B
options.text: We need to subtract more waves, which means a smaller momentum uncertainty.

options.label: C
options.text: We need to add fewer waves, which means a smaller momentum uncertainty.

options.label: D
options.text: We need to subtract fewer waves, which means a smaller momentum uncertainty.

multiple-choice.question: Who first stated the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle?
What is the significance of the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a practical limit on measurement.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a fundamental property of the universe, built into the structure of reality itself.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a mathematical formula that describes the behavior of the universe.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a scientific theory that explains the behavior of particles.
